respStmt.name: Transcription: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo and members of the Canterbury Tales Project at Oxford and Sheffield (1992-1998), De Montfort University, Leicester (1998-2005), Birmingham (2005-2010), Saskatoon (2010-2013), Virginia Tech, New York University, University of Murcia, Adam Mickiewicz University (Poznan) and Brigham Young University.

publicationStmt.publisher: Textual Communities and the Canterbury Tales Project, University of Saskatchewan

licence.p: All republication of all or any part of this transcript must credit its creators and all who have contributed to it, as listed in the sourceDesc element, and make available free-to-all any work derived from this resource under the same license.
Commercial republication is permitted, in accordance with these terms.

respStmt.name: Transcription: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo and members of the Canterbury Tales Project at Oxford and Sheffield (1992-1998), De Montfort University, Leicester (1998-2005), Birmingham (2005-2010), Saskatoon (2010-2014), Virginia Tech, New York University, University of Murcia, Adam Mickiewicz University (Poznan) and Brigham Young University.

Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green
University of Saskatchewan team, 2010-2013: Peter Robinson and Barbara Bordalejo
Virgina Tech team, led by Daniel W. Mosser
New York University team, led by David Hoover and Martha Rust, 2003-2006.

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Asterisks after names denote those who supervised other transcribers.

Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.
Institute of Book Studies and Textual Research of the University of Münster, Germany, c. 2000-2004,led by Gabriele Müller Oberhauser; transcribed by Ulrike Grassnick.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.
Brigham Young team; conversion for Textual Communities: Saskatchewan team.

body.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.

div.l: O lord oure lord . thyn name how mervelous
Is in this large world . i .spred quod she
For nought only . thy lawde precious
Ꝓprofourmed is by men of dygnite
But by mowth of children thy bounte
Fourmed is from . the brest sowkyng
Somtyme shewen they . thyn heryng
¶ Wherfor in lawde . as I can or best may
Of the and of the white lily flour
Whiche that the bare . and is amayde alway
To telle a story . I wil do my labour
Nought that I . may . encrease hir honour
For she hir self . is honour and therto
Of bounte next hir sone . of soulis boote
¶ O moder mayde . o mayde moder fre
O bussh unbrent . brennyng in moyses sight
That ravysshith downe . from the deyte
Thurgh thyn humblenes . the gost that in þᵉ alight
Of whos vertu . whan he in thyn hert alight
Conceyved was . the fadirs sapience
Help me to telle it . in thy Reuerence
¶ Lady thy bounte . and thy magnificence
Thyne vertu . and thyn grete humylite
Ther may no tunge expresse . in no science
For somtyme lady . or men pray to the
Thow gost beforne . of thy benygnite
And getest us to light . thurgh thy pʳᵃyer
To gyden us . unto thi sone so clere
¶ My kunnyng is to wayke . o blisful qwene
For to declare thyn grete . worthynes
That I ne may the weyght nought sustene
But as a chield . ꝭesy . monethis old or lasse
That kan unnethis . any word expresse
Right so fare I . and therto I yow pray
Gydeth forth my tale that I shal you say
¶ Ther was in Asye . in a grete Citee
Amonges cristen folke . a Iewrye
Susteyned by a lord . of that cuntre
For fowle usures . and lucre of velanye
Hateful to crist . and to his companye
And thurgh the strete . men myght ryde and wende
For it was fre . and open at eny ende
¶ A litel scole . of cristen folk there stoode
Downe at thenether ende . in which there were
Chieldren an hepe . I come of cristen bloode
That lierned in that scole . yere by yeere
Suche man doctayne . as men used there
This is to say . syngen and to rede
As smale children . done in hir childhede
¶ Amonges these children . was a widewes sone
A litel clergyonn . of seven yere of age
That day bi day . to scole was his wone
And eke also . where he saw the ymage
Of cristes moder . had he in vsage
As hym was taught . to knele adowne and say
His Ave Maria . as he goth by the way
¶ Thus hath this widewe . here chield litel taught
Oure blisful lady . cristes modere deere
To worship ay . and he forgate it nought
For a soli chield . wil alday sone leere
But ay whan I remembre me on this matrere
Seynt Nicholas . stant en in my presence
For he so yong . to Crist dide reuerence
¶ This chield . his lnytel booke lernyng
As he sat in the scole . at his prymer
He Alma redemptoris . herd syng
As children lierned ~ theyr Antiphoner
And as he durst . he drew hym nere and nere
And herkenyd ay . the wordis and the note
Til he the first verse . cowde alby Roote
¶ Nought wist he . what the latyn was to say
For he so yonge . and tendre was of age
But on aday his felaw . gan he pray
To expowne hym . this songe in his langage
Or tellen hym why . thys songe was in usage
Thus preyde he hym . to constrne and declare
Ful often tyme . upon his knees bare
¶ His felaw whiche that . elder was than he
Answerd hym thus . this songe I have herd sey
Was made of oure blesful lady fre
Hir to salwe . and eke hir for to pray
To ben oure help . and socour whan we deye
I can nomore expounde . in this matrere
I lierne song . I can but small gramer
¶ And is this songe . made in reủer/reence
Of cristes moder . sayde this innocent
Now certis . I wil do my diligence
To konne it . or cristemasse be went
Though that I for my pⁱrimer̉er/re shuld be shent
And shalbe betyn . thryes in anhoure
I wil it konne . oure lady to honoure
¶ His felaw taught hym . homward pⁱrivily
Fro day to day . til he cowde it by Roote
And than he sang it . wele and boldily
Fro word to word accordyng to the note
Thries on aday . passed thurgh his throte
To scoleward and homward . whan he went
On cristes moder . set was his entent
¶ As I have sayde . thurghout the Iewry
This litel chield ; as he cam to and fro
Ful myrily . than wold he syng and cry
O Alma redemptoris . enmo
The swetnes hath his hert ꝑper/parced so
Of cristes moder . that to hir to pray
He can nat stynt . of syngyng by the way
¶ Oure first foo . the spent Sathanas
That hath in Iewys . the waspis nest
Up swalle and sayde . o Ebraike peple Alas
Is this a thyng . that is to yow honest
That suche a boy . shal walken as hym lest
In youre despite . and synge of suche sentence
Which is ageyns . yowre lawis reuerence
¶ From thens forth . the Iewis hau conspired
This Innocent out of this world to chase
An homycide therto hau they huyred
That in analey / lay at a pvy place
And as the chield . gan for by for to pace
This cursed Iewis . hym hent and hield fast
And kut his throte . and in a pit hym cast
¶ I sey that in wardrope . they hym drowe
Where as these Iewis . purgen theyr entraille
O cursed folk . of herowdis al newe
What may youre evil trise . yow availe
Murdre wiloute certayne . it wil nat faile
And namely theyr honoᵘur . of god shuld sprede
The bloode out cryeth . on your cursed dede
¶ O marter soundyd . to virgynite
Now maystow syngen . folowyng en in oon
The whit lamb . celestial quod he
Of whiche the grete euᵃngelist . seynt Iohn
In Pathmos wrote . which sey they that gon
By forn this lamb . and syng a song al newe
That never fleshly . wymmey they knewe
¶ This pore wydew . wayteth al the nyght
After this litel chield . but home com he noght
For whom as sone . as it was dayes light
With face pale . of drede and busy thought
She hath at scole and ellis where hym sought
Til fynally . she gan so ferre aspye
That he was seyne . last in the Iewrye
¶ With modres pite . in hir hert enclosed
She goth as though she half . were out of mynde
To eủer/rey place . where as she hath supposed
By liklyhede . hir chield to fynde
And en on cristes moder . meke and kynde
She cryed and at the last . thus she wrought
Amonge the cursid Iewis . she hym sought
¶ She frayneth . and she prayeth pitously
To eủer/rey Iewe . that dwelt in thilk place
To telle hyr . if her chield went by
They sayden nay . but Ihus of his grace
Yaf in hir thought . withyn a litel space
That in that place . after hir sone she cryed
Ther he wast cast . in a pitte beside
¶ O grete god . that parfoᵘurmedist thy lawde
By mowth of Innocentis . lo here thi myght
This geme of chastite . this Emerawde
And eke of martirdom . the Ruby bright
Ther he with throte . I corve lay upright
He Alma Redemptoris . gan to synge
So lowde . that al the place gan to Ryng
¶ The cristen folk . that thurgh the strete went
In camen to woundren . on this thyng
And hastily therfor the prouost sent
He came anon . without taryeng
And heryeth crist . that is of hevene kyng
And eke his moder . honoᵘʳ of mankynde
And after that the Iewis . lete he bynde
¶ This chield . with pitous lamentaciounꝭes
Up takyn was . syngyng this song alway
And with honoᵘur . and grete ꝓprocessiounꝭes
They caryen hym . to the next abbay
His moder swonnyng . by the bere lay
Unnethis myght the peple . that was ther
This newe Rachel . bryng from his bere
¶ With toᵘurment . and with shameful deth ilkon
This prouost doth these Iewis for to sterue
That of his mordre wist . and that anon
He nold non suche . cursidnes observe
Evil shal have evil . that evil wil deserve
Therfor with wield hors . he dide hem drawe
And after that ; he hyng hem by the lawe
¶ Upon this bere . ay lyth this Innocent
By forne the high Auter . whiles the masse last
And after that . thabbot with his covent
Had sped hem . for to bery hym fast
And whan they holiwater . on hym cast
Yit spak the chield . whan spreynt was þᵉ holy water
And sang . o Alma Redemptoris mater
¶ This Abbot . whiche that was anholy man
As monkes ben . or ellis oughten to be
This yonge chield . to conjure he bygan
And sayde o deere chield . I halse the
By vertu . of the holy Trynite
Telle me what is thi cause for to syng
Sithens that thy throte . is kut to my semyng
¶ My throte is knt . unto my nekbone
Sayde this chield . and as be wey of kynd
I shuld have deyed . ye long tyme agon
But Ihus Crist . as . ye in bokis fynd
Wil that his glory . last and be in mynd
And for the worship . of his moder deere
Yit may I syng . o Alma lowde and cliere
¶ This welle of mercy . cristes moder swete
I loved alwey . as after my konnyng
And whan that I . my lyf shuld lete
To me she cam . and bad me for to syng
This Anteme verily . in my mynd deyeng
As ye have herd . and whan that I had sunge
Me thought she leyde . agreyn upon my tunge
¶ Wherfor I synge . and synge mote ʆser/sirtayne
In honoᵘur . of the blisful lady fre
Til of my tunge . taken is the greyne
And after that . thus sayde she to me
My litel chielde . now wil I fecche the
Whan that thy greyne . is from thy tunge I take
Be nat agast . I wil the nat forsake
¶ This holy monk . this Abbot hym meane I
His tunge out caught . and toke awey the gʳᵉyne
And he yaf up the gost . ful softly
And whan the Abbot . had thy wonndre sayne
His salt teris . stryked downe as Reyne
And gruf he felle . al plat to the grounde
And stille he lay . as he had ben I bounde
¶ The covent eke lay . upon the pavyment
Wepyng and heryeng . cristes moder deere
And after that they Rise . and forth be went
And toke away this martir . from his bere
And in a Tumbe . of marble stones chere
Enclosen they . his luytel body swete
There he is now . god leve us for to mete Amen
